user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDetach_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDetach_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             ret;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    ret = pthread_detach(impl->id);

    if (ret != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("pthread_detach: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TaskDetach_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strerror(ret)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: strerror(int) does not take pointer parameters that reference caller objects, so calling strerror(ret) cannot cause out‑of‑bounds accesses of caller objects as covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (Note: strerror returns a pointer to a static buffer and is not thread‑safe; use strerror_r if that is a concern, but that is unrelated to Rule 21.17.)
